38133531.review:
Space Engineers is one of those games that have a lot of really crippling issues, yet remain compelling. I would definitely reccomend it, since just playing around with the tools it gives you is a blast, but I think it requires the following warning: Space Engineers is a fun toy, but it's not a fun game. 

What I mean by that is, it's a lot of fun to play around with all the various things you can build in the game, but if you actually want to play space engineers as a game it's incredibly disappointing. You won't be exploring increasingly more hostile sectors of space, building colonies and taking on powerful enemy fleets, you'll pretty much just build things and then look at them for a while wishing there was something interesting to do with them. Open multiplayer servers offer no real relief from this because it's firmly in the hands of a toxic community that will shout down anyone who suggests Keen add some sensible offline protections and other anti-griefing measures, or do anything to encourage more complex multiplayer interactions than eithe sharing everything with someone, or killing them on sight. There is no money to trade with, no way to establish neutral ground that isn't going to get blown up by the first griefer idiot who happens past and no way to lay claim to technologies, capabilities or resources that give your faction a meaningful identity in the world.

Another big problem with this game is Keen's insistence that if a modder can add it they don't have to. The modding community is very active and generally great in SE, but it's almost impossible to find a mod that at the same time adds a useful functionality, is visually and thematically consistent with the base game and is reasonably balanced. For example, automatic repair nanites are an incredibly useful functionality, but the modded block creates what looks like magic whisps that repair your ship, and they are so incredibly good at it that all other means of maintenance and defense become irrelevant. An official version of this block that used small drones to add a small amount of automatic repair to take the occasional ding out of your hull would be fantastic, but right now it's either magic or nothing. 

The game is also very poorly balanced. Ships are incredibly fragile since there are no blocks that actually act as effective armor or structural parts. Force is not transmitted through solid parts, but simply destroys whatever blocks it initially comes into contact with, so there is no way to structurally reinforce your ship against collisions. Weapons have a similar issue, since they tend to simply destroy whatever block they hit. The toughness of blocks is also modeled purely on hitpoints and not on resistance, so there is no distinction between hard skinned and soft skinned vehicles, you can cut through a battleship's armor with a machine gun, and heavy artillery for dealing with armored targets doesn't even exist. Gravity Generators which should only exist to satisfy people's need to think in two dimensions can be used to build all kinds of weapons and propulsion systems that you'd find in a setting like Mass Effect. This creates a constant immersion breaking effect, where the game is supposed to take place in a relatively low tech hard scifi universe, but players can build things straight out of space operas. If artificial gravity is a thing in this universe then there is no reason why people would make energy by nuclear fission or move spaceships with hydrogen thrusters or use gunpowder to propell projectiles. Everything would work like it does in Mass Effect. 

So, overall, this game is full of really annoying issues, but it's still really fun to play around with. You'll definitely get a few hours of fun out of it. There is a similar game called Empyrion which has a much more reasonable approach to being a good game, but is much less developped when it comes to giving you the tools to make awesome ships. Both games are worth checking out. The irony is, if you mashed all the good parts of those two games together you'd get a true masterpiece title.

13683466.review:
I've been playing Space Engineers since it released on Steam. Before symmetry mode was a thing, before survival mode, before thruster damage or multiplayer or many common mechanics were implemented.  

I've got nearly 430 hours into it now, and I'll definitely rack up a lot more. Here's why. 

-Infinite possibilities. 
Do you want to build a racetrack in space and dash around in gravity-tethered go-carts? You can do that. Demolition derby? Sure, that's feasible. Starfighter dogfights? Yup, you bet'cha. Capital ship slugfests? Seen 'em, they're pretty. Just build without restrictions, build whatever you can imagine? Ayup. Survival mode? Oh, oh hell yeah. 

-Multiplayer
Sometimes sketchy, but generally reliable as of the last few patches, Space Engineers multiplayer is genuinely fun. Not in the shoot 'em up bang bang pew pew sort of way, more of the mutual cooperation so you don't all suffocate and die horribly in space sort of way. It's a huge change of pace, and the recent updates have made it feasible to do more than merely survive. You can explore, you can wander the 'verse and see all the beauty and horror it has to offer. 

-Physics
Dem physics doe. Needs a little fine-tuning in places but it works out brilliantly otherwise, and allow for artificial gravity and zero-gravity to happily coexist. Crashes are spectacular, damage from kinetic torpedoes is impressive, and for the non-combat oriented, it's just plain fun to fiddle with the physics in this game. From making orbiting satellites to devising new and innovative ways to send things flying at ludicrous speeds. 

-Update speed
KSH is awesome. They push out updates every Thursday, barring major holidays or a sudden and inexplicable bear assault on their offices. They work hard to keep the game up to snuff and it shows with just how far its come in relatively little time. 

-Steam Workshop Integration
Seriously awesome. Want a mod? Grab it. Want to play with someone's ship? Snag the blueprint. Want a new skybox? Done. New world? Easy peasy. Workshop is an amazing tool and it allows you to very easily - and very rapidly - add new spins on the base game. 

-KSH is awesome
So good they deserve their own bullet point. These guys work hard, are creative, are pretty honest about where they're at and what's going on, and push out updates and fixes like clockwork. They're enthusiastic about their product, they're in touch with their playerbase, they listen to their playerbase, and they're willing to learn from their mistakes so that they can overcome future hurdles. They're working hard and the game is only getting better with each passing week. 

If you're on the fence about this game, don't be. It's a good, solid title. It has its bugs, yes, it has its glitches and its problems, but they've spent several weeks weeding out the bulk of the problems and it plays pretty smoothly now. There's modding support, multiplayer, survival mode, creative mode, and they're rolling out exploration-oriented content - plus patches every Thursday. Not much beats that. 

If you like  building games, buy it. If you like mining games, buy it. If you like exploring, buy it. Some folks say it's minecraft in space, and in a sense it is. It's virtual legos for sci-fi gamers and hopeful shipbuilders, and it's just flat-out fantastic for it. Strongly, strongly recommended.

69285160.review:
I recommend this game, however, it's not all good.

I bought this game back in 14' just after the multi-player update was added. It's been a wild ride. 6 years and near 6000 hours.
The company that makes the game, Keen, hasn't always made the best choices and is very questionable at times. Their most recent choice of officially releasing the game and adding DLC was one of the poorer choices. Though the DLC is often good content, they've been known for releasing weekly updates every Thursday up until a few years ago. Then it was once a month, then every few months. 
The game still isn't where they promised, such as with even decent AI. Since they've added planets, they haven't added a single NEW planet until the last update and it's not even in the solar system you spawn. 

For building or multi-player survival with friends it's like no other. It's enjoyable and wonderful, however the limited end game content makes the game dull after awhile. 
If they'd add more to explore, more randomly generated worlds and star systems for example, AI that you can actually interact with, I'd be happy. As is, the game CAN be fun but it won't keep your interest forever, or long in many cases. The reason I have so many hours in the game is from building in creative and posting my creations. I doubt a 10th of my play time is survival.

Solo: It's alright.
Multi with friends: great
Multi with random people: Can be fun, but you deal with many trolls.
How are the developers: Good product, but feel short of their promises and are asking for more money after shady going ons and poor choices.

Play at your own risk, but it is fun and few if any games a can currently do what it can.

54771740.review:
OMG. I forgot to review....

OK. 580 hours into the game now.
It's the most versatile sandbox space building simulator out there.
There are some scripted stock campaigns and players can make their own and upload to the workshop.
But it's mostly a sanbox game where creating all the stuff you ever imagined is basically what you do.
Being able to solo this game for > 500 hours either shows that I'm a crazy person or that the game is that engaging
for tech- and space- nerds with a little bit of immagination at hand.

You can start in space or on planets.
You can mine, refine, assemble build, tear down and build again.
You can automate basically everything in the game in later stages.
Manage your energy, O2 and H2.
Create bases and space crafts in 2 different grid sizes.
Small grids are basically for smaller to medium working vessels or fighters.
Large grids are for realistic sized miners, haulers, war ships or planetary (even mobile) bases,
that can be inhabited and run by multiple players.
Blueprint your creations for later, or upload them to the Workshop.
Ah yes, and it has some weapons too. In case you care.
But you an well throw containers filled with rocks at your enemies, if you wish so.
Or toilets. The possibilities are endless...

Nice graphics (PBR), arcade- or realistic sound engine, atmospheric and space vessels.
Multiple planets and bodies to visit and build on.
Some with an atmosphere, some without.
Procedurally generated asteroids to mine ores.
All space bodies are fully voxelized. So you can basically dig through a planet or entirely mine away an asteroid.
Oxygen-simulation in ships, stations and on planets/bodies.
Remote-control of vessels/drones is possible.
Survival- and Creative mode.
Pretty stable multiplayer mode is available too - just in case you have, well,  ... friends.
In-game programming via script editor or raw C#-style scripting,
for those who want to squeeze the last ounce of engineering and nerdism out of this game.
The game is also moddable and there are tons of awesome mods and extra blocks on the workshop.
There are some things to spice the game up a bit. Like random ships that pass by and that can be disarmed and captured.
Drone attacks, random encounters of abandoned space ships.
And on planets, there is some hostile fauna. All of that can be enabled or disabled at wish.
The latest update brought some economy/player/NPC-trading onto the table, which is nice.

Very active and vocal developer. No dumb microtransactions. Just some cheap cosmetic DLCs.
And the coolest community manager around.

So if you are even remotely interested in space tech
and have enough immagination and ideas to fill your world with - this is the game to get.
And it's even more fun when you have some friends on a private or public server.

>> Need to create? SE: Hold my beer...!

140395657.review:
When building in this game, it is important to make your ships and space bases airtight, so that your character doesn't suffocate. However, when Keen decided to add a 'weather feature' to the game, all of this became a little less relevant. Because of poor design choice, the snow and fog from the new weather system found its way into every part of the game, INCLUDING every 'airtight' section. This was brought to Keen's attention. Hundreds of players reported the same issue via the bug report thread on Keen's website. 

Over the course of three years, the requests to fix the issue continued to pile on, with no response from Keen. After three years, Keen posted that the fix was declined (without any further comment or explanation). They simply placed a tag on the post in the bug report forum, effectively closing the issue. 

This company couldn't care less about their player base and will always take the easy/lazy way out when an issue arises. Steer clear.

55483650.review:
I love and hate this game. It is everything I've ever wanted in a space survival game, and it's everything I didn't want in a singleplayer survival game. 

The building system is amazing and satisfying; it's like you're 10 years old again and you're fighting your siblings' spaceships with your own. And then you introduce a survival aspect where you also need to manage your oxygen for basic life support, suit energy to power your tools and also basic life support, and hydrogen levels to be able to zip around at light speed in a jetpack. To do this, you need to mine resources and pump out components through automated assembling machines and refineries and the like. Where this game shines, it absolutely shines above everything else. You can make automated mining drones and sit back in your chair while they do all the work; or you can do it all yourself in the slowest and most inefficient but still engaging process ever conceived, you can add a huge 10x10 drilling system onto your main ship and have all the minerals automatically get processed without having to transport anything from A to B, or have a secondary mining ship that you connect to your main ship so that your main ship doesn't have a bunch of ugly drills on it. When Keen introduced the stone refining into the core ingots you need to make all the basic components, this game shot up from a 6/10 to an 8/10 instantly for me. You didn't have to jump from the Iron asteroid to the Silicon asteroid a hundred times just to survive, instead you could just plant yourself on top of a big, bland one and let it mine and mine with a giant piston-pushing drilling system while you are off doing something else. The more important resources still have to found and mined on their own, which is even better, because it motivates you to actually explore for them and get the resources to create bigger and better contraptions. The mining grind has never been done better than it has in this game, in my very biased opinion.

Now, that's where the bad part comes in; finding the motivation to make bigger and better contraptions. In singleplayer, there are no NPCs, very few (if any) random encounters with enemies (unless you turn on wolves and spiders, which are absolutely ridiculous and their spawning systems are...bad). So, the only risk you are ever truly faced with is your own idiocy when you drive your ship a little bit too fast on your way to your home base in your mining ship, and realize too late that you can't slow down fast enough and crash the whole thing into your base (which is a lot more fun and exciting than it sounds). With no threats to face, why bother building big, bad battleships? Why bother creating a full-scale auto-mining operation to create an endless supply of resources? For what purpose? You don't even really need to defend yourself from anything. Keen did create an endless wave survival scenario, but that just isn't really the same kind of satisfation you'd get from something like building a giant castle in Terraria to keep out the horrors of the Eclipse, where you are being faced with very imminent threats and you are rewarded for designing a more fortified and stable base/killing machine. 

"Why not just play multiplayer instead?" Because, Chad, it isn't fun. Playing a multiplayer server in this game is not fun, unless you are playing with a giant clan of people where at least two people can be constantly active on the server, because if it's just you and like one or two friends, you're going to go offline for two days straight and come back to find that one guy grinded down your whole base and stole everything, and you spent those last 30 hours doing effectively nothing. Playing in a private server with those same friends avoids that problem, but then just comes back to the same problem with "why bother doing anything?".

I absolutely adore this game, and I'm genuinely still going to keep playing it on and off because, like I said, no game has ever come so close to perfecting space survival for me. But I always find myself reaching that point of "why am I building a giant exploration vessel? There's nothing to see except for the weird monolith that's impossible to find because my system has 4 planets and each of them are way too big for me to cumulatively waste the next 5 days searching the entire surface of for this one artifact just for the achievement.

Core aspects: 10/10
Fun: 7/10
Story mode: Don't/10

After 1089 hours of gameplay.. time for a review!

I've never been hooked to a game before... I tend to hop from one game to another.

This one is a game changer.

If you liked minecraft, sandboxes, military, building, complexity, puzzles, exploring, crafting, doing whatever you want...

This game is for you.

It's a complex game with a steep learning curve. But when you get the edge of it, this game breaks the limits of many games out there. (watch for the links at the end of the review)

I play most of the time in Survival PVP Multiplayer (because objectives and challenges increases in a big way compared to pure PVE in this game i.e. military component gameplay), and sometimes in Creative to experiment new designs, weapons and new engineering processes.

Many will complain about the lag, stability, bugs unfixed for months... it's all true but Keen opened their software for the community to help enhance it further, server admins and community developers to push the limits of what is possible while Keen work on the core component of the game. To some degree, you need to accept to adapt. If that doesn't work for you, then don't buy this game. Personally, I don't have any problems in adapting, working around bugs and enjoy everything this game has to offer so far. This is definitely one of the best game I ever had in my collection.

23288857.review:
Review after 1.0 Release at 4269 Hours Played - Updated from the Early Acces 1969 Review.

Hello all, I am Purrfect-Blinky and I have been playing, Streaming and Youtubing this game since 2014, so here is my updated review of a game I still want to play daily even though it has its major flaws and is showing its age :)

My first review was in the year of 1969, if game hours were years... the hour I uploaded the Apollo Moon Rocket to the workshop, and the hour I was ready to move on I thought… yet it has been another 2300 hours and I seem to never be done with this ‘’game’’ experience. We have seen some great progression, some new pitfalls, and some letdowns. So let’s discuss again why this game is still on my mind some years later.


To compare with other games, how I feel that this game keeps on working for me is the fact that it gives creative freedom enough to build nearly anything, and the community is keeping the experience alive with custom scenarios, active community interaction from the devs and fans. We see this same kind of engagement still active with other games that have this kind of integration. Skyrim and Minecraft come to mind as games that held up as part of the community that kept making free content.

Overview
So, what is in this game? Space Engineers is a pure sandbox game with some game modes tacked on by the developers as an afterthought. The primary selling point is the destruction mechanic of voxels, both for player-made grids and chunks of rock. 

Gameloop(s?)
This destruction mechanic makes it possible to physically dig into asteroids and planets, gather materials, and use those to build a better mechanical grid. You have tools to destroy and collect these materials in the form of Drills and a functional system to manage your ship’s inventory. I wanted to list the things you can use to collect and improve your collection method… yet there is only 1 thing to use.. a Drill… big or small, it’s still a single version of a single block that stands at the core of the what is meant to be the core game loop, collect resources and use them to make better contraptions. There are no mining lasers, nanobots, titanium alloy super drills… no. Just one… one speed, one thing.

This is true for almost everything that is part of this ‘’survival mode’’ that is the one that has goals and features and balance. It baffles me that we have more variety in batteries, rotors and thrusters, (there are even upgrade modules! Super interesting! Right?… yet they only work with refineries and furnaces… the least interactive part of the game) and the tools that all these contraptions are built around have 1 of a kind. It seems that Space Engineers is lacking in depth. I rarely play the game as an exploration game, no, I never play it as an exploration and survival game. There is no end-game, there are no wonderful vista or great creatures to find. There is just you and the physics engine, and your imagination (AND MODS TOO!). This is why after doubling my hours, I still want to “play”. 

Building Mode
I play in creative, I am a “Builder” for this game, I share my creations to the workshop and even create videos using them. The way you build in this game is pretty expansive. That is mostly thanks to the size of the smallest block or ‘grid size’ in this game. That size is 50x50x50cm. That's half of most games that use voxels or blocks for their physics. Meaning that you can make builds 8 times more detailed! And ofcourse, when you fly, drive or float your creation to a crash or conflict, it breaks aparts like a beauty. 

4/7 Perfect Score

Controls
This game is available on XBox 1… but I can’t imagine making anything on a laptop keyboard… not to speak of a controller. This game should have rebindable controls but as for now this is all hard-coded. It takes a lot of hours to get used to them. I have, after all these hours, still no mastery over the rotation controls for blocks… So they are far from intuitive. Interface is also still a mess, and part of why I never want to manage any inventory or ship interface is because there are millions of screens with scrollbars, tabs and whatnot. And they are mono-chromatic so good luck finding anything with visual que’s. Luckily there is a search bar. Again why this game would be impossible with anything other than a full keyboard setup. It is faster for me to type in the block name I need to place than it is to search through my ‘’quickbars’’ (only 9 blocks are available ever on screen) and select it from there.

Score: 
9/ 500 blocks per interface

Physics
This game breaks a lot, it misses its collision frames or desync your creations on a server, yet it keeps steady and pretty when there is little to no stress. Normal gameplay will usually go fluidly and without issue, resulting in an average crash of 1 every 10 hours of play. But that was because you wanted to copy something too quickly or you tried to run a million parses of a single script on that single frame… Or you loaded the wrong world and it was too old and had memory leaks to spare… The physics are functional enough to run this, and gives plenty of physics based shenanigans to base your wacky contraptions on.

Score: 
Clang/Twang

Multiplayer
Recent patches really improve the synchronization between players when playing online. This becomes most clear in the high energy content created by the community. Racing with rovers was not possible a few years ago as people would fall through planets, get stuck or randomly explode. I have had some very satisfying experiences during stream and community driven events. So for me this mode is very functional. There are some issues with scripting but that becomes only a problem once you start deep diving into ‘’developing’’ this game.

Score:
Compilation Error/404

Community Content
This game lives and dies with its community. There are awesome mods to use in this game. This ranges from Custom Levels, new blocks & models, skyboxes, custom scripts to run and blueprints. The blueprints are actually part of the game, as they are for your own use to replicate ships you designed earlier in another game mode or world, and even import those of others. This way of community content integration means that each time you play you can find something new. That keeps the game interesting and fresh every time you boot up. or it gives you a reason to keep building and keep sharing, as the system is directly integrated with the steam workshop, with well over 10k designs and content pieces to browse through

Score: 
5/5 Stars with a thumbs up and added to favorite. But there is one guy that keeps automatically downvoting anything I post :/

This game is still a creative beauty, but I will only recommend it to those who enjoy creating Grid-Based 3D models while also putting them to use in an Multiplayer Environment. For the solo-players I would recommend looking elsewhere (in a game like ARK for example), as the depth of Space Engineers Survival Mode is anything but deep.

Final Verdict: 
Xocliw, Aragath and the team keep on working! This game is not finished just yet!

[h1]Awesome at first, but....[/h1]

This game is every minecraft players wettest dream in terms of creativity, vehicles and movement themed in a space enviroment. it has everything you need: physics, thrusters, planets, space, asteroids and basically infinite possibilites to build smth....a rover? no problem, there are weels that work. a space rocket? sure attatch some hydrogen tanks and mine ice and youre ready to go. always wanted to build and program drones? JUST MAKE ONE!!!!

[b]this game all in all is an awesome game. 
but wheres the catch?[/b]

the catch is, that this game never had the intention to be a multiplayer game. BUT it desperately needed one since you kind of have nothing to do after you progressed to a certain point ingame. that point is pretty much when crafting your first jumpers in order to move faster through space.
the whole way to that point is basically always the same: 
[list]
[*]planet mining (which means finding all the ressources ofc)
[*]get into space
[*]space mining (same with planet mining)
[*]building a space station
[*]build jumpers 
[/list]
this takes about 5-20 maybe up to 30 hrs depending on how familiar you are with the game.


thats because theres no real story, no NPC (except the idiotic "encounters" which can be added) yes this is a sandbox game but it would have so much potential if id had a story. because after you are kinda done with those points theres nothing left but base building or start a new game and repeat mentioned milestones.

[b]if SE has a MP...what is the problem with SE multiplayer?[/b]

well as i mentioned above the game studio never had the intention to implement a multiplayer which lead to a multiplayer mode that is basically unplayable. there need to be drilling restrictions, mods that delete junk in space and on planets, restrictions for certain physics, flyspeed lowering and so on. this all results in a "slowed" multiplayer experience since the servers would crash. they just cant handle more than 2-4 players doing stuff that you just do in this game. building large ships with more than a few players can be a real pain in the ass and lead to destruction of the whole thing or constant server crashes.

all in all this game is awesome, i spent a few hundred hours myself ingame on steam and maybe a few more offline on LANs. The core gameplay is fine, but I think Keen's focus isn't. The singleplayer is fantastic once you know what you're doing, and progress has a very visible impact. For example, starting on the Earth-like planet and finding cobalt is a huge leap forward in what you can accomplish as it allows you to build thrusters. Compared to something like Minecraft where there's so much to find but very little of it amounts to much. 

I will say that after """completing""" survival, which for me was building a big enough ship to get out of Earth's atmosphere and then making a ship to explore space, I felt very let down. There wasn't much incentive to create a space station or a bigger ship besides being able to say that I did, compared to the monumental feat that making a ship capable of leaving atmosphere was, which gave me more gameplay. 

So really the only options in terms of replay value is starting on a different planet, which still has the same cycle of "set up base, mine, make ship, leave planet". Maybe I'm unambitious but I got bored pretty quick. 

Multiplayer is something different. With friends, the fun is endless. The work of building and gathering materials is made more fun with a helper, and it feels good to accomplish something together. You can then have ship battles, or race buggies, or whatever. 

The shitty thing is that Keen isn't focusing on either of these types of players. They keep adding DLC which has little gameplay impact and doesn't benefit either Singleplayer or Multiplayer With Friends. The Decoration blocks are just that, the Economy pack has no use with friends and doesn't give the Singleplayer anything they haven't already mined or crafted. 

For some stupid reason Keen focuses on Multiplayer with Randoms. The only possible explanation is that they envision some sort of Elite Dangerous MMO type thing with players interacting and doing jobs, but that just isn't feasible. The playerbase is too small and largely resides in Singleplayer or Multiplayer with Friends, the map is too enormous and unpopulated for players to run into each other and Multiplayer with Randoms just becomes a case of "You're basically in singleplayer but sometimes the server will horribly rubberband".

TL;DR: Keen keeps focusing on developing for a specific playerbase that doesn't exist and the playerbase that does exist is being left out.

23111579.review:
Been putting this off for a while now, but due to recent spates of negative reviews i think it would be a good idea to make one, if only to make people more aware.

First off before the actual review i will write a warning to newer players.

This game is unfinished, do not judge it based on its current bugs as they are being fixed. 

People who claim that development is taking too long need to realize that this was being developed by a very small dev team for quite some time until relatively recently (and a good portion of the current dev team is fairly new to game development), that they are working on two games at once (medieval engineers), and that they used better part of a year developing planets at the demands of the community (which a few members of the long term community think was a mistake. That is open to speculation). In other words, cut them some slack.

This game is EXTREMELY GPU and RAM intensive, i do not suggest running it with less than 8gbs, (16 recommended). Also bear in mind that some planets will refuse to load on low end GPUs and that others will run badly. For example you will run Mars at 30 odd fps on a GTX 750ti, 50-60 on a 980. Earth and the alien planet will run at 50-60 fps on a GTX 980ti (basically a titan x with less vram). I also hear that AMD cards and CPUs run worse than their Intel and Nvidia counterparts, though this is inconsitant.

As such i STRONGLY suggest you stay away from planets if you have a weaker GPU, i can manage 40fps on intel integrated graphics in space.

Multiplayer is currently broken, though new netcode is on the way and indications are that it is nearly complete. Stay away from dedicated servers until it drops, private games with 2-6 people run perfectly fine for the most part, though i do not recommend using pistons and rotors, they will invoke to wrath of Clang (the patron god of Space engineers and utter ruin).

That just about covers it for the warning, i will add more as i either remember things or otherwise find out more.

---------------------

Now, for the actual review.

Space engineers is a semi realistic sci-fact voxel based building and exploration game (emphasis on the building part).
In this game you will build, mine and fight pirates (single player) and other players (multiplayer) in the hope of creating massive battleships to oppress the peasants, and defend what you own. 

You can build basically any ship from movies, other games and TV series, or something original (but mostly you will end up building flying bricks due to your lack of aesthetic skill), the only limits are your imagination, and your computer.

Mining for resources is actually very fun in this game due to deformable terrain.

The fighting part could use a little work, but it does the job fine for the moment.

The exploration element is similar (if not somewhat superior) to that found in Elite: Dangerous, difference being the main reasons are to find a nice looking place for a base, look for resources, or if you have both, look for the community made ships that are placed extremely infrequently across the galaxy. Rather than just to have your name on a planet, though you can do that too if you really want.

The UI is, to be honest a little daunting at first, but it does the job. 

The graphics are some of the best in the genre, and the models and effects are currantly being improved.

The music is decent (love the title screen song), but after a while you get a little tired of it. 

The modding community is absolutely fantastic, on par if not better than the Skyrim one.

Infact the community in general is superb for the most part. Probably the best i have found yet.

The game is updated every week on thursday, and hotfixes released as soon as they are finished.

Youtubers for this game in general are great, i suggest VideoSage, XP gamers and W4stedspace.

That about covers it for the review. 

TL;DR To me this game is fantastic and has the potential to be even better, and it looks like the devs are going to deliver.

8.5/10

Edit: Before putting a dislike in, make a comment so I know what you disagree on and how i can help fix it.

12488456.review:
Space Engineers combines space sim with building and does so extremely well. While the Early Access has a lot of bugs, mostly affecting multiplayer, it is still a blast to play building and flying whatever type of ship you want. It has more than just simple building blocks (the default armor blocks) including things like reactors, solar panels, gatling guns, turrets, pistons, rotors, cargo containers, and more - all of which work and have their own functions. Carefully-designed slope blocks allow you to build ships and stations that only look somewhat "blocky", compared to the cubes-only approach of other building games. 

Space Engineers supports mods like nearly no other game does, with the ability to add mods to a server, and have the clients automatically download the same mods from the Steam workshop. Because of this approach, everybody in a multiplayer game runs the same mods, all without an external modding program! So you see Earth in your skybox? So do the other players. Got custom weapons for your ship? So does everybody else. I expect this server-based mod approach to become more common to where it becomes the standard. 

For Early Access, Keen has done an excellent job with updates and hotfixes that come out weekly (on Thursdays), meaning you can log in once a week and see something fresh, as well as see that progress is being made constantly. This shows me they are serious about the game and they aren't going to just shelf this game before release or before it's ready. 

With the update for players to manually control ship turrets, as well as the player-faction features, this game is becoming more and more co-op supportive, where you can control a large ship with multiple players in different roles. Then you could use that ship against other players' crews in PvP, or fight AI once that is implemented (or when mods add AI ships to fight). 

Some of the more interesting things you can currently build include: gravity drives, remote-controlled torpedoes, orbital drones, retractable weapons, rotating antenna arrays, giant miners for strip-mining asteroids, detachable countermeasures (decoys), automatically-opening doors (sensors), and escape pods. 

Once they fix the Early Access bugs and add enough features to release out of Early Access, I have a feeling this will be in many top 10 lists of best space games for a long time, if it isn't already.

54492271.review:
Space Engineers Delivers

Despite years of criticism, rumors that it was being abandoned, Space Engineers delivered. Is it a perfect game? No. Does it need some serious CPU and a decent Graphic Card? Yes. Is there any other game like it? 

Not even close. 

While Dual Universe and the much maligned Star Citizen are still hovering in Alpha and have yet failed to materialize their promised potential (my money is on Dual Universe), Space Engineers has produced a finished product that for a small fee will produce untold hours (when you see the total hours I have spent on this game, consider that I run a tech company and teach theology part time and I am writing a book) of enjoyment for those who want a true open Sandbox Space Engineering game. 

Let's clear the decks with what this game is [b]not[/b], it's not a space exploration game such as No Man's Sky (another game that has rebounded beautifully). This is purely a game for those who want to start from total scratch and build bases, factories, ships, mining equipment and who find joy in solving actual engineering issues. 

Let me give you an example. When you start out, you will be using a hand drill. Tedious. So you start by building a quick base for protection. Then you want to build a small mining ship so you can increase the efficiency of your mining. But it needs power, more power than your starting Windmills can produce. So you build solar panels, but now you need more batteries to store the power. Which means you now how to go find ore deposits in the ground. You can walk around and try to detect them with your very limited scanner in your hand drill, but that takes forever. So you end up building a rover with a more powerful ore detector, and on and on and on. One problem solved creates three more challenges. 

And when I say [i]build[/i] let me clarify. You can download blueprints from other users that have spectacular designs, but to do that you have to have some level of advancement to begin to set that process up (and it is not done for you; yes you will have to engineer this also). You will discover the joy of designing, testing and flying or driving your first vehicle. And then proceed to cry when it tips over and you realize there is no way to turn it over (yes, you will have to engineer that issue also). 

In Space Engineers, gravity is a bitch. It is unforgiving and will cause massive damage and issues if one is not careful. The physics, while not perfect, is excellent for a game play that is unique. For instance, I built a small mining vehicle whose starting weight is around 42,000 Kg. When fully loaded with rock and ore, around 138,00 Kg. When empty, it is nimble, but when loaded if flies like a bloated pig. Just like it should in real life. When designing ships you must take in account weight versus thrust, yet it is not so complex that you can't simply experiment and once you get enough experience be able to build ships with out trying to do complicated math formulas. But you can if you want. And they do appear to be relative consistent (see the forums). 

Now if your still reading this, your either gagging or salivating. If the latter, it gets better. The game by itself is well worth the small amount you pay (even for the DLCs, which I will get to). But it is the modding community (5th most active last time I checked) that pushes this game over the top. The mods are simply incredible, and add everything to additional NPC encounters, pirates, law enforcement (um say if you like to 'acquire' resources from other ships), food and daily survival and modifications to even some of the game core. All made possible by the brilliant decision to open source the code by Keen Software. Keen even adds some of the most beneficial mods to the game itself; a nod to the modders coding prowess. The second brilliant decision by Keen was to allow actual programming to [i]run inside the game itself[/i] which not only allows for easier modding but even allows users with a little bit of scripting knowledge to write custom scripts in their games to automate tasks. 

While I have just started exploring the world of hosted Space Engineer servers; they themselves are another world(s) and most are heavily modded for different styles and types of game play. From cooperative worlds to ones that lend themselves to Space Battles (another whole topic), there is one you will probably find that fits your style of play. 

One complaint I see is the DLCs (additional content you buy from the developer). IMHO, this is ridiculous. I have purchased every one of them and will continue to do so. I want Keen and his dev group to keep pushing this game to new heights. DLC's I would definitely pay for in the future would be ability to 'jump' to different star systems (should be difficult as hell to build those engines and power requirements that are extreme), bigger solar systems with more variety (And water? Yea, I know it must a difficult one) and different NPC/Alien type encounters (there are some good Mods out there for this already).

Space Engineers is simply the most fun I have had since MineCraft. If your the creative problem solver, this game will be your crack.

41487289.review:
Short version :

Great potential wasted into a dull sandbox, but kept alive by modders.

Long version :

Space Engineers has an enormous potential. I spent over 1200 hours on it so I definitely cannot say its not worth the price. However ...

The great potential of this game is wasted, making it a glorified sandbox with no incentive to do anything. Evey game I played, I started being excited about having to settle up, build my first miners & reach for space ... only to figure out somewhere in the way that I had no reason to do this, no reason to arm up, no engineering challenges or anything. There are no objectives, no rewarding exploration (yeah you can find some generic abandoned ships in space, but at that point you dont need anything more than you already have), no relevent enemy force. So everytime, I just end my game with a 'meh', juste wondering why Ive been playing. 

Despite countless forum posts, comments and live stream interventions along the years asking Marek from Keen Studios to focus more on gameplay. In those messages, many great new ideas of gameplay improvement, ways to implement them, and carefull demonstrations on how lack of gameplay is preventing this game from goign to 'somewhat ok' to 'really great'. Yet Marek recently made a clear statement that he didnt want to improve the gameplay as 'he feared that would interefere with the players habits'.

I think having a strong leadership on a game project is great, but can becomes a serious flaw when you end up not listening to anyone else than yourself.

In the end, the only thing that saves this game is the amazing community of modders that tries hard to fill in the huge holes in this game with new content, gameplay and opposing forces. Im not sure if Marek realize his game would be dead in the water without those guys efforts. At least for me I can confidently say that I would not play this game at all if it wasnt for the mods.

Despite all their qualities, relying too much on mods for your game content results in a unclear and unbalanced experience, hard to approach for new players. Also, mods are very vulnerable to new game versions breaking them, and we've lost quite a few disgruntled modders to that reason already.

It seems that since Marek's recent interview were he basically states the gameplay wont change, the community's been reacting negatively, hence the huge drop from "very positive" reviews to "mixed". Im joining that movement as I hope that if Marek wont listen to players, he will listen to sales.

If a different new approach was to be taken, Id revisit this review.

25460450.review:
This is a complete rewrite of my review to bring it up-to-date.

[h1]It's Dead Jim[/h1]

What you are witnessing is the death of yet another EA game.  The only problem is, all the fanboys shouldn't have tried to shut out people like me raising the alarm that KSH has done this before with another game called Miner Wars.  Yes, I warned everyone early on.  So, you now have a game that updates only when they push paid DLC on you while glaring problems in the game still exists and are rarely fixed and if they do fix a problem it causes other issues that they won't fix again until another DLC is released.

[h1]THE PROBLEMS[/h1]

Don't get me wrong, this game had so much potential but it started out - cheaply coded.  How can you make a huge open-world space game and then develop your matrix using float knowing every architecture rounds differently knowing the client and server will have discrepancies over the matrix?  Why hasn't this been fixed yet?

 How can you not think to develop with something that can support the vastness of space?  Like, oh, I don't know, init64?

The game lacks any and all content.  People say sandbox to try and protect the developers but what they don't mention is the sandbox is supposed to have SAND.  This game is a big, empty sandbox with no sand.  You can build your ship, but... Welp, that's all.  You can do a little exploring but once you've seen a few points of interest, you've seen it all.

The only threats of death in this game, literally are bugs.  No not arthropods, we're talking game bugs, the kind of things that just randomly happen.  Here is a true story:  My son and I were about to land on a planet and as he goes to lock his landing gear his gears go through the terrain, and his ship gets stuck half-way into the terrain and starts exploding.  I stop the server, restart with the backup 5 mins before hand and login knowing our ships are in motion at this point.  We get to the load screen and it sits there and sits there.  What is it doing?  It's actually waiting for your ship to crash so it can load you at the re-spawn screen.  No kidding - you login and you will sit there for 5 minutes until your ship stops before you can load it.  The game literally waits until you die to let you load in.

As I said, you're more likely to die and lose your ship to a bug than any in-game NPC or careless collision.

[h1]I TRIED TO LOVE IT[/h1]

A while back, feels like eons ago, I tried to fix the game (actually I kinda did).  This was after being told by the developers that fixing the issues of multiplayer was "impossible".  Tell me something is impossible with code and I'll purposely prove you wrong.  What they meant to say was, "We're just too lazy to give a s**t about fixing it".  Really, this should have been the tell tell that something was wrong.  But fanbois supported them and made excuses for them.  Well, I fixed it by creating a simple wrapper to filter the bs out of the network traffic.  It worked too.  Grabbing a perfectly random player from the forums to help me test, he agreed it was the greatest fix to SE he'd seen yet and said, "You should give this to KSH as a gift to help the community".

I went to the forums with the intent of doing just that, posted the video of the performance improvements and told them a little of what I had done.  The devs went silent while the fanbois ravenously flamed and trolled me.  It's cool though, my feelings don't get easily hurt but when Iieval (the guy I'm talking abou that helped test) went to defend me, he got the same treatment and the video was deleted and called a fake. 

My mind was honestly blown.  I've never seen a gesture of altruism get met with such hostility, anger, and hate.  But why?  Because fanbois are mentally unstable - they identify as the game so any criticism to the game is received by them as a personal attacks.   If you criticism the game, even if  you fix the game and show up their precious developers, you have just committed a personal attack on their honor and they must respond in kind.  That's the psyche of a fanboi.

[h1]COMMERCIAL SUICIDE[/h1]
Actually, it's not the fanboi's fault though.  Keen surrounded themselves with their fanbois early on, even took one of the most ravenous fanbois, gave him a job and had him be the community relations manager.  Yeah, you heard that right.  Xocliw, the guy in all of the Keen videos now was and still is one of the biggest fanbois of KSH and ALL of their games.  Of course you want someone who is kindly to your company, but it became more extreme when they tried to show that they were listening to their community by doing a LIVE Q&A.  The only problem is, you had to be one of those fanbois that filled out an Eve-style application to be on that Q&A.  No kidding, 100% of the participants were 100% fanboi and never asked a hard question - in fact, most were scripted already.  The event was theater, nothing more.

Keen, by surrounding themselves with their bubble of fanbois guaranteed they would develop their game in an echo chamber.  If you play the game, just look around.  AI's that just fly in straight lines, 2 - I REPEAT 2 animals in the game, dogs (oh I'll get to that), and spiders.

I knew there was a problem when they first released the dogs, I knew something just felt scammy.  They were called "Cyber Hounds" on release and if you look at the config files, you'll see that's what they are still called.  The reason was because when they released, they would spawn inside your ship while on Earth and blow things up.  Players literally called them "Jihad Dogs".  Also, within hours a patch was made to allow people to turn them off.

But what happened just before the patch is the perfect demonstration of the evils of fanbois and bringing them into your echo chambers.  Understand that at this point, they had already done their damage.  With Keen refusing to ban them or even discipline them in their forums, no one said anything negative to Keen fearing they would be trolled or cursed out by the fanbois.  So when this update with cyberhounds dropped, before ANYONE could even download it, they were literally commenting to the patch notes with, "Wonderful!", "Courageous!", "outstanding!", "Best release yet!".  It was like watching a snake consume itself.

Keen could piss all over their community and these fanbois would praise them for the rain and then troll and attack anyone that questioned the temperature, color, and pungent odor of the liquid.

[h1]STILL HOPE[/h1]
Not really hope, but there is still a reason for people who have bought the game to still play.  Mods and Modders.  I will say this, the game is absolute dog s**t.  But after you start adding some mods, you can actually have some fun with the game.  Unfortunately, mods aren't supported and Keen makes that very clear by delisting your server the moment you add a mod to it.  They also give you a big warning pop-up when you enter "experimental" mod to install a mod basically saying they're not responsible for any gaming oddities. 

I'm not going to give this game a positive review with that kind of behavior. I love the mods and modders in fact they SHOULD be compensated (and I do donate when I see links in the workshop), but the developers and the game is trash.  The developers have made it extremely clear they are simply "done" with the game.  When a feature breaks, instead of fixing it, they throw it in the experimental pile with the modding.  They just announced they'll be adding oxygen and pressurization to that list.

My advice if you haven't purchased the game:  Don't.  If you have, install mods, particularly weaponcore, defense shields, Modular Encounters, Rival AI, and TORCH for the performance fixes.  

That's one more thing I want to say right quick before I end this review.  For YEARS keen has been talking about how this is impossible and that is impossible and these modders can literally do what they call impossible in a matter of days.  The devs are trash.

40901042.review:
I [i]wish[/i] I could recommend this game. I really do, I've sunk damn near 2000 hours into Space Engineers, making hundreds of ships, space stations, ground bases and even the occasional rover.
But the game doesn't seem to have a clear goal, and with the dev's most recent updates and livestreams, it's becoming fairly evident they want to wrap this game up as fast as possible and move on to another project. 

Now, the big issue with this is while Space Engineers has some fantastic features, the game can't even run a dedicated server with less than 6 people connected at once, all doing different things without having major sim speed issues and lag. And god forbid if you try to do any big battles using capital ships.

The worst part of the entire development process of this game is the insane waffling of features. Right now, everyone is clamoring for ladders to be added, since there's currently only two ways to move vertically in the game:
A: Use a Jetpack 
Or
B: Make a staircase

Jetpacks in trhis game take fuel, which early on can be a finite resource until you can find more. And stairs take up a LOT of space inside ships or whatever creation you're using. My understanding from the latest Q&A Stream the devs had is that they have literally no plans for the future of this game. Despite the players who love this game [b](myself included!)[/b] begging for Ladders, a Female Character Model, New Multiplayer Netcode and much much more.

Understand that if you're buying this game, you're buying it for what it has [b]RIGHT NOW[/b], don't expect any major additions to this game in the near future.
If you're craving a space sandbox/builder survival game, I'd recommend looking at the competition and what they're offering before making any final decisions about buying this game.
It can be fun, but at the same time, it's absolutely infuriating.

EDIT:
Some people seem to have confused my negative review with not liking the game. I very much enjoy the game, but it lacks direction and stability I think it needs for serious multiplayer gameplay.

My review was meant to tell prospective purchasers that they need to buy it for what it has NOW, not what it might have, because I am uncertain as to the future of the game and how stable it will be for MP and crazy SP.

I picked negative because there was no "Mixed Opinion" option.

EDIT 2:

It's pretty clear that what I read at the time that I made this review is out of date regarding the Devs planning to abandon the game, take it with a grain of salt, since it did seem that way for a time.

82067614.review:
It's basically Minecraft in Space and I love it. In this game you can build your own spaceships, stations, asteroid bases, planetary bases, rovers, etc. Building a carrier that can launch small fighters? Sure! A space station in orbit with planetary bombardment capabilities? Why not? A mining platform that automatically drills itself into asteroids to collect ores? Of course! The possibilities are endless...

Just like in Minecraft, you can either play in survival mode, where you have to collect resources to build things or in create mode where you can just build whatever your heart desires. The survival mode is not as fleshed out in my opinion and I usually stick to creative mode. Multiplayer is also supported and while it's not perfect, it works well enough to enjoy it.

What this game does well is modeling physics. Unlike in some other games, your creations will adhere to the laws of physics. Usually this works as intended but for some creations the system might break, producing ... unexpected results that can result in your ship taking heavy damage or be destroyed. Unless you build some very advanced creations, this will not be a problem however.

Another great thing about this game is the Steam Workshop Support. You can download tons of creations to add to your world and - of course - also upload your own. You can mod your game to add new features, blocks and behavior. Just be mindful of the performance hit when you mod your game excessively. Performance overall is something to be aware of though. As your creations get larger and more complex, your FPS will tank hard, eventually coming down to single-digit levels for huge creations. This can and undoubtedly will diminish your experience at some point.

However, the game is still very enjoyable and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes space and Minecraft-like games. The price tag is very reasonable, even the Ultimate edition which includes additional blocks still seems fairly priced.

78758393.review:
The scope of this game is absolutely incredible. You better expect to put in a lot of time investment and research, but it really pays off. 

For me, Survival mode is where the fun is. Start out on a planet in a crashed drop pod, and gradually learn the ropes, cobbling together a tiny base from hand drilled rock. 200 hours later and I have a massive asteroid facility with a fleet of fully automated mining drones, vast sun-tracking solar arrays, a 3d printer for SPACESHIPS and a wide assortment of spaceships, both military and utility (and so much more). All hand-crafted from individual parts and painstakingly programmed.  This game makes me feel like the Sci-Fi space engineering badass I've always wanted to be. The pesky space pirates don't stand a chance.

Disclaimer: Yes, it can be janky as hell and frustrating. Yes, performance can be a bit shit. Yes, you totally need mods and scripting to reach the games full potential. But, if you're willing to look past these problems, it's so worth it.

I'm saying no because I would not recommend this game to other players. I assume that other players here are the "common" players and that is where there is a huge problem. 

This game is pretty fun. You get to build buildings, stations, ships all from scratch and in any way you want. a personal highlight so far has been building a station inside of an asteroid and building a 3d printer to print small fighter ships. But that's about where it ends.

There is no meaningful PVE encounters built in. Some mods have done their best to add in some endgame PVE content but it's executed pretty poorly. The enemy AI is terrible at flying, but has laser precision with their auto turrets. But to be fair, making good AI is pretty hard, and a ton of games fail at this.

So what is the endgame? We started on an earth like planet and once we got to space, we realized there was no reason to go to any other planet. There are no special resources, or ships, or alien life to be explored. Just more rock, and the same materials on Earth.

The actual endgame is taking dozens of hours to build a large ship, and fighting other players with dozens of hours. But the ship combat is unfulfilling. There are some cool options/strategies, like drones and ship positioning (think broadsiding). But basically it's just ships shooting like crazy then limping away. All of this is done on privately rented, very powerful servers that will practically stall when only ten players do anything remotely interesting. (Huge Problem)

And that's the endgame. Shooting other players for no reason. There are no vanilla NPC's walking around (wolves are stupid) So I don't recommend people buy this game. Maybe on a huge discount? Getting to space was pretty neat. But until there is a massive optimization and end game content update it's a ravine of a game. (very deep, but vary narrow)

20856888.review:
All the negative reviews of the game, saying that the game is unfinished, with poor graphics and optimization...they're not wrong. But they aren't right, either.

The game is in an alpha state, and there WILL be bugs, specially in multiplayer (but that's going to be fixed in about 3 months when new netcode is implemented). 

Right now the game is almost feature complete. There is way more things to explore than in other games. You could spend a thousand hours on the game yet you wouldn't explore it fully.

What annoys the people and make them post negative reviews are the details. It's true that the game has undergone some reckless patches, without any clear goal (remember they patch the game once a week. That puts big pressure on the devs, needing to release features to keep the community happy), but the new roadmap for 2016 states that things will start to be tidier.

[b]New models, new textures, new UI. [/b] The game is not going to stay like this forever; it will eventually become and look like a finished game. So although the models aren't that pretty, the features are there, aren't they?
Even though cargo containers might be ugly modeled, they are functional, and that's what counts.

About the "reckless last patches". If you bothered to read, you'd know that the new game netcode is being developed RIGHT NOW, so don't expect big patches unless the netcode is released.

Let me tell you some of the things you have right now at space engineers:
[list]
[*] Pistons: Yeah, they are buggy right now IN MULTIPLAYER, but that'll get fixed. In single player they are functional.

[*] Rotors: Hanger doors, Robotic arms, hidden turrets, moving platforms...

[*] Conveyors: Item sorting, automated power / item transfer between ships...Combine with rotors for epic.

[*] Planets: Fully moddable planets which add several engineering challenges, such as getting out of the atmosphere of a planet (yes, there is gravity and it's not that easy to get out of the planet, specially in survival), or surviving the long trips between planets.

[*] Remote control and Drones: You can send your ship out of the planet without even being aboard. Obviously, this is not easy to do, and requires engineering (and maybe, programming skills if you want more functionality)

[*] Programmable Blocks: There is an extensive API out of which you can make automated ship station, item sorters, radars, status reports, cargo managers... Or just display the time in an LCD.

[*] Huge modding community: The developers are also focusing on adding modding support to many areas of the game, and right now there is a bunch of mods that ADD REAL FUNCTIONALITY to the game, plus cosmetic ones that look absolutely amazing.

[*] Awesome ship designs in the Workshop: You can get an idea of what kind of ships you can make taking a look at some designs made by other people. You can recreate ships from films and series, like star wars, or from games like FTL. The game offer great building mechanics that make it suitable for a wide range of styles.

[/list]

So yeah, the game is not BUG FREE, nor FEATURE COMPLETE, but right now it can give you LOTS OF FUN for many hours, and many engineering possibilities with all the mechanisms / machines included currently in the game.

The only serious con I'd see right now is optimization. Seriously, if you want to play on planets with large ships, be sure to get a high-tier gaming rig. I have a 970 which seems enough for the game, and an i5 (this game is CPU intensive!!)
The game will eventually get more and more optimized for less powerful computers whatsoever.

TLDR: Despite all the bugs and placeholder models in the game, it offers many features which are already in the game and WILL give you a lot of fun, specially if you play with friends -expect bugs if you play multiplayer -.
Don't get scared because of negative reviews. The game right now is just developing new netcode and thus the weekly patches are not AWESOME and they introduce some bugs to the game.

This game has great potential that unfortunately will never come to fruition due to the developer's complete apathy towards actually improving the game, rather than milking it with barrage of DLCs that only affect cosmetics.

I will go over the two areas the game drew me in and the shortcomings associated with them that personally killed the game for me:

1) The in-game building is similar to Minecraft, that is, you can build buildings, aircrafts, spaceships and rovers and pretty much anything else big or small using a multitude of blocks, combine this with many "adjustable" blocks such as pistons, lights, landing gears, control panels and ... to create incredible-looking spaceships and such if you were to put the time into it; However, that is all there is to it, "good-looking" ships and structures are all you can build, as the dated engine of the game [b] severely [/b] hinders the scope of things you can do and/or how realistic they will look.

For example, the maximum speed any ship can reach in the game is a whopping ... 109 m/s. A speed which you also attain by just using a [b] jetpack [/b], I can't genuinely relay how disheartening it is to build a great looking ship with multiple hydrogen thrusters only for it to cap it's speed out after 2 seconds and move at the pace of snail afterwards.

The weaponry is also very unimpressive, and considering how dull and pointless the survival is or pretty much any combat feels, there is no motivation to encourage to you make a decent looking combat ship either as it's again, purely for the looks.

I mean just imagine it, if Bugatti's looked that great but then only got up to 100 km/h or you saw a amazing fighter jet but then you realize that it only has two 9mm pistols attached under it, do you get my point? After your first ship, the hype genuinely dies extremely fast.


2) This game practically does not receive any updates that affect the game in an important manner whatsoever, you can just check for yourself in the link below, even changelogs tagged "MAJOR UPDATE" are just a huge array of bug fixes and DLCs that add LITERALLY nothing except reskins of already existing blocks.
[url=https://support.keenswh.com/spaceengineers/pc/announcement/update-1-199-heavy-industry_1] This Link [/url] is the latest update the game has had, and it has been tagged as a major update, you can also check the rest of the updates on the right.

That is why I say this game has potential that is never being realized with such developers; This game has a great idea and space is an amazing bed for creative cultivation, however it needs a lot of work and constant stream of meaningful updates/overhauls for a while before I can say it is worthwhile.

TL;DR Game has potential but too many unaddressed problems and it does not seem to be getting fixed considering the developer's history and actions so far.

39186096.review:
After so long in-game, I can't remember what year it is, let alone day. Updates come from the sky-Gods every Thursday of usually mundane bug fixes. All I know is that I must continue building. To be more serious, this game does have some serious flaws, some may find those to be a lack of purpose or significant story mode, for others it could be the strange bugs that sometimes nullify hours of work for the smallest change, or it could just be that it could get really boring.

Personally though, this game has mostly been a blast from start to finish, and many of the glaring faults fade over time as you recognise the "right" way of doing things (sadly it takes a hell of a long time to work around so much). There is relatively realistic physics simulation, huge engineering possibilites, awesome Sci-Fi style creations all over the workshop and just waiting to be built, full in-game C# based programming and scripting that has resulted in an electronic warfare related arms-race and so much more. 

There *is* purpose in the game, it just takes time to find, and requires a hefty amount of initial imagination and slogging to get through, which I realise is a large point against the game, but if you're interested, check it out. It may just steal your god-damn life.

33538626.review:
I want to like this game, I really do, it's a really good time killer but often i find myself struggling to find things to do.
Space engineers has excellent creative freedom, allowing you to build any ship/base you can think of, however it's strength is also it's greatest weakness in that once you build these ships there is a limited amount of things you can do with them, because of this singleplayer in particular becomes quite boring rather quickly.

Creative mode is probably the best aspect of this game, however the problem of limited things to do is here too, as the already small addition of survival aspects and rescource collecting are removed entirely, leaving you with just ship building. The workshop community are fantastic builders though, hats off to them for the stuff they make.

The game does support mods, and often servers will have several to add on to the vanilla rescources, again here the workshop community is great and I can't knock them at all.

Speaking of community, multiplayer SHOULD be the redeeming factor for this game, but it falls short.
There's no inscentive for friendly player interaction or trust outside of private servers; more often than not players will group with their mates and hide off in the far corners of the universe, never to be seen again. This is because the build time/destruction time ratio is so huge that players have no reason to trust anyone or pick anything resembling a fair fight (Which, in itself, is rare) which makes pvp scarce and one-sided, even on servers dedicated to it.

Servers often struggle to meet the needs of a dozen players, which heavily contrasts the expansivness of the game worlds, making servers feel flimsy and empty.
I imagine a game with huge player corperations duking it out for territory with frequent fleet battles, abit like EVE online but with voxel building, and i'll scream off the rooftops about this game if that ever comes to be.

Until then I can't recommend this game. Unless of course you like building things; by all means get it then, it's good at that atleast.
